greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangular array of generalized Narayana numbers: T(n, k) = 4*binomial(n+1, k+3)*binomial(n+1, k-1)/(n+1).
comment: T(n,k) is the number of walks of n unit steps, each step in the direction either up (U), down (D), right (R) or left (L), starting from (0,0) and finishing at lattice points on the horizontal line y = 3 and which remain in the upper half-plane y >= 0. An example is given in the Example section below.

The current array is the case r = 3 of the generalized Narayana numbers N_r(n,k) := (r + 1)/(n + 1)*binomial(n + 1,k + r)*binomial(n + 1,k - 1), which count walks of n steps from the origin to points on the horizontal line y = r that remain in the upper half-plane. Case r = 0 gives the table of Narayana numbers A001263 (but with an offset of 0 in the row numbering). For other cases see A145596 (r = 1), A145597 (r = 2) and A145599 (r = 4).
link: F. Cai, Q.-H. Hou, Y. Sun, A. L. B. Yang, Combinatorial identities related to 2x2 submatrices of recursive matrices, arXiv:1808.05736 [math.CO], 2018; Table 2.1 for k=3.
R. K. Guy, Catwalks, sandsteps and Pascal pyramids, J. Integer Sequences, Vol. 3 (2000), Article #00.1.6.
formula: T(n,k) = 4/(n+1)*binomial(n+1,k+3)*binomial(n+1,k-1) for n >=3 and 1 <= k <= n-2. In the notation of [Guy], T(n,k) equals w_n(x,y) at (x,y) = (2*k - n + 1,3). Row sums A003518.
Identities for row polynomials R_n(x) = Sum_{k = 1 .. n - 2} T(n,k)*x^k:
Row generating polynomial R_(n+3)(x) = 4/(n+4)*x*(1-x)^n * Jacobi_P(n,4,4,(1+x)/(1-x)). - _Peter Bala_, Oct 31 2008
example: T(5,3) = 10: the 10 walks of length 5 from (0,0) to (2,3) are
UUURR, UURUR, UURRU, URUUR, URURU, URRUU, RUUUR, RUURU, RURUU
maple: for n from 3 to 12 do seq(T(n, k), k = 1 .. n-2) end do;
results.author: _Peter Bala_, Oct 15 2008
